Graphical abstract A MnII-Schiff-base catalyst was synthesized and covalently immobilized onto Pyrolytic Carbon surface from waste tyres (PCox ), resulting in the heterogeneous catalyst MnII-L@PCox which was evaluated for degradation of methyl orange (MO) using NaIO4 as oxidant. Importantly, no additive as co-catalyst was needed. For comparison, a reference heterogeneous catalyst MnII-L@ACox was also tested, using Activated Carbon (ACox ) as carbon matrix. The catalytic and recyclability data of MnII-L@PCox catalyst demonstrate that it is superior, in terms of TONs and TOFs vs. MnII-L@ACox . To study the reaction path, electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy was used to monitor the redox evolution of the Mn-centers. Furthermore, a full mapping of the catalytic degradation of MO and product formation was carried out using LC-MS and HPLC. Combining catalytic and spectroscopic data we discuss the protective effect of the PCox matrix on Mn-centers; it allows their rapid redox evolution to higher oxidation states. Keywords Heterogenization Pyrolytic carbon Supported complexes Manganese complexes MO degradation 1 Introduction Annually, azo-dyes are produced and utilized in large quantities in diverse applications including textiles, paint pigments, printing inks and food coloring [1–4]. The presence of dyes in effluent and industrial wastewater entails considerable environmental/economic concern, including health risks [1–7]. Among various oxidative transition metal catalysts, manganese is advantageous, e.g., as it is economic, efficient and environmental friendly metal [8–10]. Non-heme manganese complexes are often easily prepared/handled as catalysts and this is a reason why they have received considerable attention [8–10]. In this context, new, efficient, selective, low-cost and easy to prepare Mn-catalysts remain at high demand in the field of oxidation catalysis [8]. So far, catalytic degradation of organic dyes by non-heme MnII-HCO3 − catalysts has been reported under mild reaction conditions, e.g., using H2O2 as oxidant [11–16]. Rothbart et al. investigated the oxidative degradation of Orange II by MnII-HCO3 − and peracetic acid [13,14]. Ember et al. postulated that the formation of highly reactive manganese intermediates in the presence of carbonates in aqueous solution, with no coordinative ligand, can lead to degradation of organic dyes [12]. H2O2 as oxidant can be used in cases where dismutation of H2O2 does not occur, and relatively mild redox potentials i.e., around 300mV, are sufficient [8–14]. In the case where higher redox potentials have to be accessed and/or H2O2 dismutation is a limiting factor, oxidants other than H2O2 have to be used. Chellamani et al. reported the kinetics and mechanism of methyl–phenyl–sulfides oxidation catalyzed by MnII(salen) complexes, with NaIO4 as oxidant [17]. Catalytic efficiency is only one of the key-prerequisites for technologically exploitable Mn-catalysts. Stability/reusability of the catalyst is an equally important parameter for catalytic reactions. In this context, recovery and reuse of the used catalyst is a challenging task that has to be considered. This can be achieved by replacing a –successful- homogeneous catalyst by an active heterogeneous one. Heterogenization changes the synthetic process toward a more desirable and clean one, providing advantages e.g., such as easy handling, easy product separation, catalyst recovery and lower waste’s production. To this front, the heterogenization of a metal-catalyst on a solid support has been proven fruitful in the recovery and reuse of catalysts [8–10,18–25]. Furthermore, the use of inorganic support materials with covalently-bound active centers as heterogenised catalysts endows the homogeneous systems with attractive features such as zero catalyst leaching, catalyst stability and recovery [8–10]. During last decade, our group [8,10] and others [18,21–23,25] have advanced the synthesis of successful Mn-based catalyst on SiO2 supports, producing in this way heterogeneous Mn-based materials that are efficient for catalytic epoxidation and environmentally benign. Despite the legacy of SiO2, carbon materials constitute also an interesting family of supports for the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts, due to their physical and chemical surface properties [19,26,27]. Carbon materials display advantages over other widely used supports, e.g., SiO2, such as [i] resistance to both acidic and basic media, [ii] ability to modify their chemical properties to control polarity and hydrophobicity, [iii] stability at high temperatures and [vi] lower cost. Although carbon-supported catalysts are considered to be the best choice for many reactions, currently, few large-volume processes use these systems, and less than 1% of the activated carbon production worldwide is used as catalyst support [19,26,27]. The difficulty originates from the need to a better understanding of the various parameters interplaying, i.e., carbon surface groups, polarity/hydrophobicity and porosity, in conjunction with the redox evolution of the metal-catalyst. To address this task one has to combine analytical and in situ spectroscopic techniques as guidance for the mechanism and rate limiting steps. To this front, non-heme Mn catalysts have been extensively used, however a comprehensive detailed monitoring of catalytic cycle intermediates is difficult detectable, due to the transient character of reaction intermediates. They are very few examples i.e., in Mn-salen complexes, where the Mn(III) to Mn(V) transition has been detected by Electron Paramagnetic Resonance [28–30]. Using carbon from recycled tyres to catalytic technologies is a more demanding approach, as the evolution of automobile industry entails the disposal of a tremendous number of waste tyres which are responsible for a series of environmental problems. Among numerous technologies of disposing waste tyres, pyrolysis seems to be a promising, high-valued and environmental friendly technology. Pyrolytic char (PC) is one of the main products obtained after the pyrolysis process. PC has a contiguous structure with carbon black and this confers it with the general properties of carbonaceous materials, previously mentioned. PC bears abundant oxy functional groups inherently, without need for further oxidation process [31]. Several studies have reported the use of PC and Activated Carbon (AC) as adsorbents of several organic and inorganic compounds [31–33]. However, using carbon from recycled tyres as support for heterogeneous catalysts has not been –so far- reported in literature. Although, some reports refer immobilization of Mn catalytic complexes on the surface of activated carbons [34,35], however only Ji et al. [36] have reported immobilization of chiral MnIII-salen complexes on the surface of pyrolytic carbon for catalytic epoxidation of olefins. Very recently, a new synthetic methodology to covalently anchor MnII-Shiff-base catalysts onto activated carbon (ACox) has been reported by our group [34], resulting in heterogeneous MnII-L@ACox materials. These materials are effective and selective oxidation catalysts toward epoxides with H2O2 [34]. Herein, we have used the synthetic protocol developed in [34] to prepare heterogeneous MnII-Shiff-base catalysts onto pyrolytic carbon from recycled tyres (PC). The catalytic performance of the Mn-L@PCox hybrid material was evaluated under strong oxidative conditions using NaIO4 as oxidant. Degradation of methyl-orange in aqueous solution was studied as a model reaction. For the first time we exemplify that a highly recyclable Mn-L@PCox heterogeneous catalyst, prepared using pyrolytic carbon from recycled tyres as support matrix, operates in aqueous solution. Importantly, no co-catalyst was needed. To further shed light on the underlying catalytic mechanism, we have combined catalytic and in situ Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) [28–30] spectroscopy. Based on detailed catalytic and EPR data a consistent catalytic mechanism is discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Analytical grade acetonitrile (CH3CN) and ammonium acetate were purchased from Aldrich and Merck respectively. Methanol that used for the washes of the heterogeneous catalysts was purchased from Merck. Ultra-pure water was provided by a Milli-Q system (Millipore). Sodium periodate (NaIO4) and methyl orange (C14H14N3NaO3S, MO), that used for the catalytic procedure were purchased from Merck. Nitric acid 65% (HNO3) and ethanol both were purchased from Merck, (3-chloropropyl) trimethoxysilane from Fluka and manganese (II) chloride tetrahydrate was purchased from Sigma Aldrich. 2.2 Characterization methods Isotherms of nitrogen (N2) adsorption–desorption were measured under liquid nitrogen temperature (77K) with a porosimeter Thermo Finnigan Sorptomatic 1990. The Specific Surface Areas of the samples were determinate by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method (BET) using the adsorption points in relative pressures (P/P 0) between the values 0,01 and 0,30. The points of isotherms' desorption show both the size and the distribution of pores' size using the Barret–Joyner–Halenda method (BJH). All samples were measured under high vacuum(10−4mbar) anaerobic conditions in 120°C for 10h. X-ray powder diffraction data were collected on a D8 Advance Bruker diffractometer using Cu Ka (40kV, 40mA, k =1.54178Å) radiation and a secondary beam graphite monochromator. Diffraction patterns were collected in the 2h range from 2 to 80°, in steps of 0.02° and 2s counting time per step. The obtained data are showed in Fig. 1 in Supporting information. 3 Synthesis and characterization of synthetic catalysts 3.1 Pyrolytic carbon The char was derived from the pyrolysis of used rubber tyres at 450°C in oxygen-free atmosphere under vacuum for 4h. Elemental analysis found (%): C 72.53; H 4.70%; N 4.76; S 2.84; O 15.17. 3.2 Surface modification of pyrolytic carbon For the oxidation of pyrolytic carbon (PC), 5g were added in 90ml 65% v/v HNO3 and refluxed at 105°C for 6h. The obtained solid (PCox ) was separated by filtration, washed with distilled water until pH∼7 and dried under reduced pressure at 40°C for 12h. DRIFT-IR: characteristic peaks (cm−1) were as follows: 2946, 2856: ν(C–H); 1710: ν(C O); 1585: ν(C C); 1250, 1213: ν(CO). Thermal analysis (TG-DTA): the thermogram of PCox exhibits a broad peak in the range of 130–420°C, corresponding to the decomposition of the formed COOH surface groups, which are attributed to a weight loss of 10% (ca. 2.2mmol g−1), and confirmed by elemental analysis. The intense peak at 600°C is assigned to the combustion of carbon support and the total weight loss of PCox sample in the temperature range of 20–700°C was 100%. The PCox had an average surface area of ca.74m2 g−1. All data are summarized in Table 1 . 3.3 Synthesis of carbon-based Mn complex The synthetic strategy published recently by our group [34] for covalently grafted metal complexes onto the surface of activated carbon (AC) has been adopted here for developing supported Mn-complex onto pyrolytic carbon. That is, (a) 1.2mmol of ligand L and 1.0mmol of (3-chloropropyl)-trimethoxysilane were refluxed for 48h in 10ml of MeOH under N2 at 60°C leading to L-OS silane-precursor. (b) After cooling at room temperature, 1.2mmol of MnCl2.4H2O in 10ml MeOH, were added to this solution and stirred overnight at room temperature leading to the precursor MnII-L-OS. (c) To this, 0.5g of oxidised carbon PCox and 5ml EtOH were added and refluxed at 60°C for 24h. The resulting material MnII-L@PCox was separated by filtration, washed several times with MeOH and EtOH and dried under vacuum at 60°C for 12h. The catalyst MnII-L@PCox was formed after hydrolysis and co-condensation of precursor MnII-L-OS with the OH surface functional groups of modified pyrolytic carbon PCox . MnII-L@PCox: Metal loading: 0.40mmol g−1. DRIFT-IR (cm−1, selected peaks): 2952, 2868: ν(CH); 1708: ν(C O); 1689: ν(C N); 1587: ν(C C); 1215: ν(CO). Thermal analysis: the thermogram of MnII-L@PCox shows a weight loss of 20.2% that corresponds to the decomposition of the anchored organic ligand L. This material had a BET surface area of ca. 94m2 g−1. All aforementioned data are listed in Table 1. 3.4 Catalytic MO degradation Experiments of MO catalytic degradation were performed under aerobic conditions in stirred tubes using 20ml aqueous dispersion of the heterogeneous MnII-L@PCox catalyst, containing the appropriate amounts of MO. The pH of the catalytic reaction was 6.8 (value of Milli-Q water) and the temperature was maintained at 25±1 °C. For comparison, the catalytic experiments were also run for the well characterized MnII-L@ACox catalyst, which was prepared as detailed previously [34], using commercial Activated Carbon (AC). We underline, that the homogeneous catalyst MnII-L was not soluble in H2O, thus did not operate catalytically in H2O. In contrast the heterogeneous MnII-L@PCox and MnII-L@ACox catalysts were easily dispersed in H2O and – as we show herein – presented excellent catalytic performance. Control experiments, without catalyst, show that oxidative degradation of MO in the presence of NaIO4 did not occur. Moreover, no catalytic degradation was detected using MnCl2 ×4H2O as catalyst. In addition, control experiments were performed to substantiate that the observed degradation of MO is catalyzed by the heterogeneous catalysts. Thus, in typical catalytic control experiments, the solid catalysts were filtered after 30min of reaction and the MO degradation into the filtrate’s solutions were monitored by UV–vis. The data showed that no further MO degradation was observed in the filtrate ensuring that no leaching of the active supported Mn(II)-component occurs. Putative MnII-leaching during catalysis was also cross-checked by EPR spectroscopy; that is, the filtrates were monitored by EPR and no signals attributable to manganese ions were detected. Adsorption tests on the surface of heterogeneous catalysts MnII-L@ACox and MnII-L@PCox show that no adsorption phenomena of MO were noticed on the modified materials; on the other hand, high adsorption capacity was noticed on both unmodified matrixes ACox and PCox (see Supp. Info. Fig. 2). To optimize the catalytic conditions of the catalysts, several experiments have been carried out. The optimum molar ratio was found to be [cat]:[MO]:[NaIO4]=[1]:[225]:[450] μmol. In this operating conditions, the initial solution potential was E h =580mV vs. Standard hydrogen electrode (SHE), calibrated by a 10mM/10mM aqueous solution of K3Fe(CN)6/K2Fe(CN)6 (pH 6.8) E h reference =236mV [37]. For a standard catalytic run, 2mg of MnII-L@PCox or MnII-L@AC were dispersed in 20ml of aqueous solution, corresponding to 31μM and 34.5μM of Mn, respectively. The heterogeneous suspension was sonicated in a low-power bath sonicator for 60s. For the recyclability tests, after each catalytic run, the heterogeneous catalysts MnII-L@ACox or MnII-L@PCox were recovered by centrifugation, the solid washed with water: methanol [50:50 v/v] and dried at 60°C overnight. Subsequently the recovered solid catalyst was reused for a new oxidation reaction under the same catalytic conditions. Into filtrates, which were scanned by EPR, no Mn-signals were detected. It is worth to mention that in all catalytic reactions there was no need of co-catalyst addition e.g., such as ammonium acetate or bicarbonates, as mentioned in the literature for numerous reported analogous Mn-based catalysts [8–10,32,33]. 3.5 UV–vis measurements The UV–vis spectra for MO recorded in distilled water at pH 6.8 show two absorption maxima, the first band observed at 270nm and the second one at 466nm [12]. The band at 466nm was used to monitor the effect of the catalytic degradation of MO. UV–vis spectra were recorded using a PerkinElmer spectrometer Lamda 35. To ensure that the measurements obey a linear Beer–Lambert law, the samples were diluted to 25μM giving an optical absorbance of Abs466 =0.627 in agreement with the molar extinction coefficient ϵ 466 =25,080 Μ−1 ×cm−1 (see Supporting information Fig. 3). 3.6 HPLC chromatographic conditions For high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analyses, samples were taken from the reaction mixture and filtered through a 0.2μm Whattman filter. The residual dye and the degradation products were determined using the following chromatographic conditions: mobile phase: a mixture of [acetonitrile (A)] –[ammonium acetate (10mM, pH 6.8) aqueous solution (B)]. The gradient program used was: [0–2.5min] 100% aqueous solution, [from 2.5min to 5min] 10% A/ 90% B, [from 5 to 8min] 20% A 80% B, [from 8min to 17min] 70% B 30% A, with a flow rate of 1ml/min. HPLC analyses were carried out using a Dionex P580 liquid chromatograph equipped with a 25cm×4,6mm C18 column, and a Dionex UVD 170U Photodiode Array Detector. The column temperature was 23°C and the total injected volume 100μl. The wavelength that the chromatograph of MO recorded was 470nm whereas the wavelengths of the products recorded were 350 and 260nm.The instrumentation was running under the Chromeleon V620 software. 3.7 Mass spectrometry An ultra-performance liquid chromatography – electrospray ionization – mass spectrometry (UPLC–ESI–MS) system including an Accela Autosampler, an Accela LC pump and a LTQ Orbitrap mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Germany) was used for the identification of MO degradation products. A C18Hypersil Gold column, (100mm×2.1mm i.d., 1.9μm particle size, Thermo Fisher Scientific), was used at 40°C. Injection volume was 10μL and flow rate 300μL min−1. Gradient mobile phase composition was adopted using water/5mM ammonium formate as solvent A and methanol /5mM ammonium formate as solvent B with the following program: 90/10–0/100 in 10min, and 90/10–0/100 in 20min. All ESI–MS experiments were acquired in the positive mode and the ESI-source parameters were as follows: sheath and auxiliary gas flow rate 35 and 10 (nitrogen, arbitrary units), respectively; source voltage at 2.9kV; capillary temperature at 320°C. For fragmentation study, the voltage of the HCD collision cell was set at 35eV. Prior to analysis, the orbitrap mass analyzer was externally calibrated, in the scan range m/z 100–1000, to obtain mass accuracy with ±5ppm. The tuning parameters adopted for the ESI source were: capillary voltage −30.00V, tube lens −120V. The analysis was performed using a resolving power of 60.000. UPLC–ESI/MS system was controlled with X calibur software version 2.1 that included chemical formula calculator used to provide chemical formula and mass accuracy values. 3.8 Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectroscopy A continuous-wave Brucker ER 200D X-Band EPR spectroscopy equipped with a perpedicular mode cavity was used. The spectrometer was running under home-made LabView software [38]. All EPR measurements were conducted in quartz EPR tubes of 5mm. 2mg of heterogeneous catalyst dispersed in 150μl of methanol solution were added in EPR tubes followed by the addition of 10 equivalents of NaIO4 to a final ratio [cat]:[NaIO4]=[1:10]. EPR measurements were performed at liquid nitrogen temperatures (77K). 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Synthesis of the catalyst The synthetic process, developed recently by our group for active oxidation catalysts covalently immobilised onto the surface of activated carbon AC, has been applied here for the synthesis of the heterogeneous catalyst MnII-L@PCox using pyrolytic carbon as support. This procedure, depicted in Scheme 1, involves: (i) oxidation of the pyrolytic carbon PC with concentrated HNO3 leading to PCox with increased surfacialCOOH groups (ii) reaction of the ligand L with (3-chloropropyl)-trimethoxysilane to form L-OS silane-precursor, (iii) reaction of L-OS with MnIICl2 resulting in the metalated silane-precursor MnII-L-OS and (iv) anchoring of the metalated silane-precursor MnII-L-OS on the surface of the oxidised pyrolytic carbon PCox via hydrolysis and co-condensation with the formed OH functionalities of the PCox . Herein, the final obtained heterogeneous material is named MnII-L@PCox . The DRIFT-IR spectrum of the MnII-L@PCox (see Supp. Info., Fig 4) displays bands which are assigned to the structural units of the oxidised pyrolytic carbon PCox and the organic ligand L. Specifically, the bands at 1708cm−1 and 1689cm−1 are attributed to the ν(CO) and ν(CN) stretching vibrations respectively. These vibrations are shifted after the metalation of the organic ligand L proving the coordination of the MnII with the imine-nitrogen and keto-oxygen groups [8,10]. The TG-DTA thermogram of MnII-L@PCox (see Supp. Info. Fig. 5) exhibits a 30.2% weight-loss in the range of 150–400°C, which is attributed to 10% of COOH surface groups from the parent material PCox decomposed in the range of 130–400°C, and the difference weight-loss of 20.2% is attributed to the decomposition of organic moieties from the anchored organosilane and organic ligand L. This percentage corresponds to a loading of 0.42mmolg−1. The thermogram shows also an intense peak at 450°C corresponding to the combustion of the carbon support; however this maximum is shifted to lower temperature for the grafted catalyst MnII-L@PCox vs. the parent matrix PCox . The observed weightloss of the sample MnII-L@ACox in the temperature range 20–700°C was 94.1 %. In MnII-L@PCox the solid residue, SiO2 and MnO2, corresponds to a weight loss of 5.9 %. Mn-loading determined by Flame Atomic Absorption spectroscopy (PerkinElmer Analyst A700) was 0.40mmolg−1 (3.5%); therefore Si-loading was ca. 0.42mmolg−1. All the aforementioned data are listed in Table 1. 4.2 Catalytic decomposition of methyl orange The catalytic degradation of methyl orange was monitored by UV–vis spectroscopy. Fig. 1 (black lines) illustrates a typical UV–vis spectrum of MO in aqueous solution. The strong absorbance at 466nm attributed to a conjugated structure formed by the azo bond with strong influence of the electron donating exo-cyclic dimethylamino-group [39]. The band at 270nm is ascribed to the π–π* transition related to the aromatic rings [39]. As presented in Fig. 1A, during the catalytic reaction, multiple changes are observed in the UV–vis spectrum. More particularly, catalytic degradation of MO by MnII-L@PCox results in progressively diminishing of the band at 466nm, loosing >70% of its initial intensity within 90min. This can be taken as an indicator of cleavage of the azo-bond of MO [39]. Moreover, a new band appears at 320nm implying a complex degradation pattern with intermediates which contribute to the UV–vis spectra. These intermediates were fully mapped by HPLC and LC-MS, as discussed in the following. For comparison, catalytic degradation of MO by the heterogeneous catalyst MnII-L@ACox , see Fig. 1B, was recorded by UV–vis also. In all cases, using the intensity of the azo-bond at 466nm, we derived a kinetic profile of the main reaction step, displayed in Fig. 2 . To substantiate that the observed degradation of MO is catalyzed by the heterogeneous catalysts, e.g., no leaching of the active component or putative demetallation occurs during the catalytic processes, control experiments were performed. In such experiments, the solid catalysts were filtered after 30min of reaction and the MO degradation into the filtrate's solution was monitored by UV–vis. The data showed that no further MO degradation was observed into the filtrate. Moreover, samples of filtrates were scanned by EPR; no signals attributable to manganese ions were detected by EPR ensuring that no leaching of the active supported Mn(II)-component or demetallation occurs during catalysis. 4.3 Kinetic rates Interestingly, the data in Fig. 2 (solid symbols, left-Y axis) show an enhanced kinetic profile of the MnII-L@PCox catalyst vs. the homologous heterogeneous catalyst MnII-L@ACox for catalytic MO decomposition. For instance, as shown at Fig. 2, during the first 2h 60% and 50% of MO’s concentration has been converted by MnII-L@PCox and MnII-L@ACox , respectively. After 24h, ∼10% of MO remained intact by the heterogeneous catalysts. The solution potential Eh, (see Fig. 2 open symbols, right-Y axis) shows a rapid consumption of oxidative species during catalysis. At close inspection, we observe that the Eh decreases in parallel with the degradation of MO. This indicates that oxidative events are responsible for the observed MO degradation. As we show in the following by EPR spectroscopy, this is due to evolution of the MnII centers to higher oxidation states that are responsible for MO degradation. Overall, the present data show that [i] the immobilized Mn-catalysts on carbon matrixes are effective for MO degradation and [ii] MnII-L@PCox catalyst appears to be faster than MnII-L@ACox . 4.4 Recyclability of the heterogeneous catalysts Reuse of heterogeneous catalysts in catalytic technology remains always a challenge. In the present work, the behavior of the heterogeneous catalysts was evaluated after their recover from the catalytic reaction. The catalytic data obtained by this set of experiments, displayed in Fig. 3 , show that after repetitive uses the recycled catalysts were able to activate NaIO4 in new catalytic reactions. A progressive loss e.g., approximately 15% of activity was observed after each use for MnII-L@PCox catalyst, whereas for MnII-L@ACox a 30% loss of activity catalyst was observed. Thus, MnII-L@PCox shows a higher recyclability than MnII-L@ACox catalyst. This indicates a higher stability of the MnII-L catalyst when supported on Pyrolytic carbon’s surface vs. Activated carbon material. 4.5 Catalytic Evolution of Mn-species monitored by EPR spectroscopy The EPR spectra for the MnII-L@PCox or the MnII-L@ACox catalysts are displayed in Fig. 4 A and 4B respectively, recorded at various time intervals after the addition of the oxidant. Before addition of the oxidant, the sharp lines corresponding to monomeric MnII centers, e.g., MnII (S =1/2, I =5/2), are well resolved [8,9,40–42]. Numerical simulation of the EPR spectra-as detailed in [34]- provides their zero-field splitting D =165Gauss and 55Mn hyperfine A iso =−93Gauss, which indicate that the ligand-atoms of the MnII are similar in MnII-L@PCox as well in the MnII-L@ACox catalyst. Upon oxidation with NaIO4, the intensity of the MnII spectrum in MnII-L@PCox is rapidly decreasing, due to evolution toward higher oxidation states of the MnII. Detailed mapping of the kinetics depicting in Fig. 4C, shows that within 3min the intensity of the sextet of MnII decreases to 10%, e.g., more than 90% of the MnII centers in MnII-L@PCox evolved to higher oxidation states. In MnII-L@ACox (Fig. 4B and D), the oxidative evolution of the MnII is much slower than in MnII-L@PCox catalyst. Comparison of the kinetics in Fig. 4C and D shows that in MnII-L@PCox catalyst, practically 100% of the Mn-centers evolve within few minutes, whereas in MnII-L@ACox catalyst, the Mn-centers need almost 1h to evolve a 50% of the MnII centers to higher oxidation states. As shown in Fig. 4A, a transient radical-like EPR signal is observed after oxidation at t =5s–60min. In MnII-L@PCox this signal shows a transient-time profile, Fig. 4C, and grows at the expense of the initial MnII centers. The details of its lineshape show that this signal does not originate from an isolated radical, however, further assignment is not possible. In MnII-L@ACox catalyst the radical signal is developed mirroring the evolution of the MnII centers, however in this material the kinetics is much slower than in MnII-L@PCox catalyst and the radical signal does not show-up as strongly as in MnII-L@PCox . The origin and significance of this “radical” signal is not clear, however we notice the apparent correlation of this evolution with the MnII-oxidative evolution. Since oxidation by IO4 − under strong oxidative potential (E h =550mV vs. SHE) is a 2e− oxidation step, MnII (S =5/2) is oxidised to MnIV(S =3/2). Thus we consider that this radical signal might be related with higher oxidation states on the Mn-centers. We notice that under these strong oxidizing condition in H2O the homogeneous MnII-L is rapidly destabilised i.e., EPR reveals release of the Mn-atoms in solution (data not shown). Overall, the present data reveal that the immobilization of the MnII-L catalyst on the PCox or ACox confers them with an acceleration of the evolution of MnII centers to higher oxidation states. Importantly, this redox evolution is significantly faster in catalyst supported on pyrolytic carbon MnII-L@PCox vs. the catalyst supported on activated carbon MnII-L@AC ox. This rapid redox evolution of the Mn centers is the origin of the rapid catalytic degradation of MO. 4.6 Catalytic products HPLC and LC–MS analysis Fig. 5 presents the HPLC profile of MO catalytic degradation recorded at 470nm ( ), 350nm ( ) and 260nm ( ) after 30min of catalytic reaction; HPLC profile of intact MO at 470nm ( ) is also provided (t R =10.2min). We observe the evolution of the catalytic reaction during the first 30min, i.e., the intensity of the peak of the MO was reduced, and new peaks appear before and after the MO peak. These peaks may be attributed to products formation with lower and higher molecular weight and/or polarity, respectively. To map the decomposition path of methyl orange, the catalytic reaction was monitored by accurate LC-MS too. The catalytic reaction mixtures -after centrifugation of heterogeneous catalysts- were analyzed by LC–MS after 15, 30 and 90min of reaction time. Fig. 6 (Supporting information.) shows the mass spectra of the detected oxidation products. The peak with retention time Rt =7.85min exhibiting a negative molecular ion at m/z 304.0755 and a molecular formula of C14H14N3O3S- was assigned to MO. The peaks at retention time Rt=5.41min and Rt=3.27min exhibited molecular ions at m/z 290.0601 and m/z 276.0446 corresponding to the mono-demethylated- and bi-demethylated-derivative of MO, respectively. This assignment is supported by the mass difference of 14.0154 and 28.0309 amu from the parent compound, respectively. MS2 spectra of demethylated derivative of MO showed fragment ions at m/z 275.0386 (C12H9O3N3S-, loss of methyl group), 226.0995 (C13H12ON3S-, loss of –SO2) and 155.9893 (C6H4O3S-); analogous losses were monitored for the MS2 fragmentation of the bi-demethylated MO (m/z 212.0830, loss of –SO2; m/z 155.9889, C6H4O3S-). The decomposition was observed that proceeds also via initial formation of hydroxyl derivatives of MO. That is, the peak at Rt=2.68min showed the basic molecular peak at m/z 320.0711 and on the basis of their exact mass that differed 15.9956 units from the MO molecule was attributed to oxygenated TP and more specifically to hydroxy-MO derivative. According to the MS2 spectra that showed an m/z ion at 305.0474 (loss of methyl group) the hydroxylation occurred in one of the aromatic rings. The aromatic ring, which bears the (CH3)2 N-group seems to be the more available candidate for such HO-addition due to the activating effect of the exocyclic group [6]. The corresponding keto-derivative was attributed to the ion with m/z 318.0550 (difference of 2.0161amu from the hydroxylated derivative). The MS2 spectra of the keto-derivative further confirmed that the HO-addition took place in the dimethyl-aniline ring by providing a fragment ion at m/z 155.9887 with a formula C6H4O3S− which reveals that the benzenesulfonate ring is intact. Moreover, catalytic oxidative degradation of the mono-hydroxylated product results in the formation of the corresponding demethylated species (m/z 306.0550). A poly-hydroxylated derivative of MO has been also detected i.e., m/z 368.0707 with a chemical formula C14H14N3O7S− (see Scheme 2 ). It was eluted prior to MO and assigned to the insertion of four hydroxyl groups (63.9952 amu difference comparing to MO molecule). MS2 spectra showed fragments at m/z 304.1093 (loss of -SO2), 288.1147 (loss of -SO3 −), and 155.9891 (C6H4O3S−) indicating that the benzenesulfonate ring moiety was not hydroxylated. The observed fragmentation path is known as common behavior for the benzene sulfonic acid group [43]. The formation of the corresponding quinone-analog (with m/z 366.0553 and a formula C12H14N3O7S−, (see Scheme 2) has been also detected. In analogous way to the poly-hydroxylated product, the MS2 spectra of the quinone-derivative showed a fragment ion at m/z 155.9890 (C6H4O3S) revealing that no oxidation or hydroxylation occurred in the benzene-sulfonate moiety. Finally, the TPs with molecular ions at m/z 172.9915 and m/z 156.9965 were assigned to hydroxy-benzenesulfonate (C6H5O4S−) and benzenesulfonate (C6H5O3S−) respectively, indicating cleavage of the azo-bond of MO. The major catalytic degradation pathways of MO by heterogeneous catalyst MnII-L@PCox are depicted at Scheme 2. 5 Discussion Covalently immobilization of the homogeneous catalyst MnII-L on carbon matrixes, e.g., pyrolysed carbon from recycled tyres or commercial activated carbon, provides heterogeneous catalysts MnII-L@PCox and MnII-L@ACox that are highly active for oxidative degradation of MO. The adopted synthetic procedure preserved the catalytic features of the active homogeneous catalyst being successfully embedded onto the carbon’s surface, providing efficient heterogeneous catalysts. EPR spectroscopy reveals that in H2O/IO4 − medium, the active Mn-centers evolve rapidly through MnII/MnIV states and this is correlated with the rapid catalytic degradation of MO. Detailed monitoring of the solution potential shows that the evolution of the high manganese oxidation states and the concomitant MO degradation is achieved at Eh >500mV in H2O/IO4 − medium. Recently, we have shown that the MnII-L@ACox catalyst showed improved performance and resistance to oxidative cleavage in CH3OH/H2O2 [34]. However, in that case [34] the solution potential, Eh, was significantly lower than that in the present used H2O/IO4 − system, e.g., E hmax =363mV in CH3OH/H2O2 [9] vs. E hmax =550mV in H2O/IO4 − medium. Thus, here we demonstrate that MnII-L@PCox catalyst supported on a solid-waste carbon matrix, e.g., pyrolytic tyre char, outcompetes the MnII-L@ACox catalyst. Under these strongly oxidizing conditions the homogeneous MnII-L is rapidly decomposed, e.g., Mn-leaching is verified by EPR, indicating that the carbon support protects the MnII-L active complex from oxidative decomposition during catalysis. A protective role of the solid support, e.g., SiO2, has been previously documented by our group [8–10,41,42], as well as by others [21,25]. The BET data for MnII-L@ACox and MnII-L@PCox reveal a compacted, low-porosity structure. Thus all the grafted MnII-L centers are directly exposed to the solvent-phase being readily available for reaction with oxidant and substrate [34]. Thus, the observed superior performance of MnII-L@ACox and MnII-L@PCox is – to a significant part- attributed to the protective role of the carbon–matrixes which permit the Mn-L catalyst to operate under high redox potentials. Comparing the catalytic behavior of the supported catalysts on commercial activated carbon or on pyrolyzed carbon, MnII-L@PCox appears to be faster and shows higher recyclability than MnII-L@ACox probably due to higher stability. However, more studies are under progress to address thoroughly these points. Based on LC-MS data we have mapped the main catalytic decomposition paths of methyl orange. The initial degradation path involves either cleavage of (CH3)2N-group or hydroxylation of the dimethyl aniline ring; the detected intermediate fragments indicate that both could be occurred. This was followed by further oxidation toward quinone-analogs and finally azo-bond cleavage. According to MS-MS chromatography, hydroxylations are operating exclusively on the aromatic ring with the exocyclic alkyl-amino group. Methyl orange decomposition starts from this ring, azo-bond cleavage follows, and finally, hydroxylation of benzene sulfonate ring occurs. The bulky charged SO3 −- group of the benzene sulfonate ring of MO seems to orient catalytic decomposition of MO toward the other ring which bears the (CH3)2N-group. 6 Conclusion The utility of a recycled material such as pyrolytic carbon from tyres, as a supporting material for the development of heterogeneous catalysts, has been exemplified for the first time. Herein, we present as a proof-of-principle, that heterogeneous catalyst MnII-L@PCox can be produced by covalent grafting of a MnII-L complex on PCox support material. A catalytic study was carried out for degradation of a common dye Methyl Orange in H2O. A comparative study with the homologous MnII-L@ACox , e.g., using activated carbon as supporting material, reveals that PCox offers a stable matrix that [i] protects the active Mn-centers from oxidative degradation, enabling them in this way to evolve rapidly under high oxidation potential, [ii] the carbon matrix offers a compacted structure where all the active Mn-complexes are exposed to the reaction medium minimising eventual kinetic limitations. EPR spectroscopy shows that when the active catalyst grafted on the carbon matrix providing the MnII-L@ACox and MnII-L@PCox heterogeneous catalysts, the Mn centers undergo rapid redox evolution from MnII toward higher oxidation states. LC-MS data allow a mapping of the major catalytic degradation paths. We underline that among the novelties of the present work is the successful transfer of the activity of homogeneous systems to carbon-based heterogeneous ones. Until now, this heterogenization technology has been scrutinized mainly for SiO2-based materials. Herein, we demonstrate that Pyrolytic Carbon from recycled tyres can also become an added-value material that can be used as a matrix for immobilized oxidation catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A MnII-Schiff-base catalyst was synthesized and covalently immobilized onto Pyrolytic Carbon surface from waste tyres (PCox ), resulting in the heterogeneous catalyst MnII-L@PCox which was evaluated for degradation of methyl orange (MO) using NaIO4 as oxidant. Importantly, no additive as co-catalyst was needed. For comparison, a reference heterogeneous catalyst MnII-L@ACox was also tested, using Activated Carbon (ACox ) as carbon matrix. The catalytic and recyclability data of MnII-L@PCox catalyst demonstrate that it is superior, in terms of TONs and TOFs vs. MnII-L@ACox . To study the reaction path, electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy was used to monitor the redox evolution of the Mn-centers. Furthermore, a full mapping of the catalytic degradation of MO and product formation was carried out using LC-MS and HPLC. Combining catalytic and spectroscopic data we discuss the protective effect of the PCox matrix on Mn-centers; it allows their rapid redox evolution to higher oxidation states.
